Axel Foley.Action: Casually approaches two suspicious characters, unselfconsciously and with confidence.
Hops down confidently from the top of the stack of cigarette cases, catching the two hoods by surprise.
Engages two small-time criminals directly and casually, showing ease and confidence in potentially risky situations.
Hands Carlotta and Mirsky packs of cigarettes in a friendly and casual manner while explaining their quality.
Tells Carlotta and Mirsky they can walk away if they don't like the deal, expressing a tolerant and straightforward attitude.
Counts the money and confronts Carlotta about being short on the agreed amount, implying mistrust.
Refuses to accept lower payment and insists on full amount firmly and unapologetically.
Tries to play it cool when confronted by cops, offers a plausible explanation about jumper cables.
Refuses to get down off the moving truck despite orders and danger.
Tries to play it cool by lying about his identity to the cops and attempts to de-escalate the situation with humor.

Fails to convincingly hide his identity from the cops, drawing their suspicion.
Hangs on inside the moving truck despite cigarette cases bouncing around, showing physical resilience and presence of mind.
Attempts to maintain balance and avoid injury in a highly unstable and dangerous environment.

Raises hands and stands still when police guns are pointed at him, showing non-aggressive compliance.

Emerges from under a pile of cigarette cases after the truck halts, indicating physical resilience and quick recovery.

Waves and is friendly to neighborhood kids who greet him warmly.
Welcomes old friend Michael Tandino into his apartment, despite the friend breaking in.
Jokes about needing a gun instead of a lock and about roaches entering through the open fridge door.

Parks his car illegally in front of a hydrant.
Expresses that he misses Mikey and engages in friendly conversation despite Mikey’s shady plans.

Jokes about stealing a car but refuses to engage in illegal activity, emphasizing his sincerity as a police officer.

Calls Mikey 'stupid' for forgetting his Deutsch marks but in a teasing, familiar tone.
Questions Mikey's job and background with blunt language, which could be perceived as less tolerant or somewhat brusque.
Persuades Mikey to stop drinking and come with him, showing awareness of Mikey's condition and a protective attitude.
